markers can be used instead of cable needles cables can be worked without cable ne edles by air cabling rearranging of the stitches g auge tapestry needle the length 36 rounds = 10 cm / 4 inch in cable pattern 2 the width is very tricky to assess in my socks 40 stitches span 9 cm / 3 54 inch if relaxed that is 44 5 stitches for 10 cm/ 4 inch recalculated however extended width of leg can easily reach 3 2 cm/ 12 6 inches all around sizes s m/l additional adaptation for xl three sizes differ in the number of stitches a lot due to the period of the stitch pattern double sided cables are less elastic than regular fabric therefore numbers are high however for a delicate narrow feet 70 stitches for s easily accommodate the leg and go smoothly over the ankle if you need more space to pull socks across the heel i suggest using 2 5 mm/ 2 us for legs and 2 25 mm/ 1 us for heels and feet for more space around ankles i strongly advise 80 stitches that is m/l size finally some need larger and wider socks some like to have a dense fabric obtained by 2 mm/ 0 us or even smaller needles and are willing to invest additional time to knitting for those knitters the 90-stitch size adaptation is described in the section after the toes one more comment the size m/l is almost ideally reversible the only difference between the two sides are slightly different longitudinal positions of cables however size s and size xl are a bit less reversible because of the odd number of repeats of the stitch pattern however a person with a lot of experience as a knitter and an eagle s eye can see that the instep has either purls or knits at both sides and not one of each if this is a problem choose 80 stitches for s and v ery thin needles abbreviations k p knit m1l purl make one left
